text: Am confused. On Wednesday Theresa May told me she spoke for the public, who apparently are united behind her. Is this a fake public?
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: This. And it’s corollary - the anti intellectualism that runs through British broadcasting. Anything that even looks like an idea is treated with disdain. And it’s worst in centre. Eg IMO BBC NI radio often one of best places for considered discussions
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Quote of the day in today’s @FT. In fairness to the Portuguese Pm who wouldn’t be ‘confused’ after talking to Jeremy Corbyn about #Brexit

text: The use of the phrase ‘deliver’ in British politics these days is becoming increasing bizarre

text: Even Brexit won’t stop the sub Boris Johnson EU nonsense stories it would seem. Bendy banana anyone?

text: This looks like a cracking training session with the excellent @JennaCorderoy. What she doesn’t know about FOI isn’t worth knowing. Definitely head along if you can

text: In my experience they are appalled by it, and very angry. Understandably so

text: There’s a bunch of really good reasons why border checks are a terrible idea (most obvious is will be an instant target for terrorists). Personally I deeply, deeply hope they never appear
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: The least surprising piece of news today....
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: There will be customs checks on the border if there's no deal. I'd expect within six months or so. The €39bn will be paid regardless.
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Watching EU leaders talk about Brexit over-riding sense is that they are very fed up with it and, consequently, might do something rash just to have the whole thing over. UK likely to severely underestimate this danger
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Do come along to this in Belfast on ‘Brexit day’ - a fantastic line up (and me)
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Ashamed to say was my first ever visit to Glasgow Women’s Library to speak the wonderful @sca_net with the inimitable @Chitgrrl
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: This is exactly why I've been trying to get a bookie to take a bet on No Deal by mid-April (not April 1st)

text: "Northern Ireland is being nudged towards a point of no return." @NewtonEmerson on the money, again
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Perhaps but maybe then he should say ‘polls suggest’. All this talk of ‘the people want’ can strike a rather anti democratic tone
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Increasingly @BBCkatyaadler is the only voice of sanity - understanding where EU is - in the craziness of #r4today
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Jeremy Hunt tells #r4today that ‘people don’t want’ a long Brexit extension but are happy with a short one. How does he know this?
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Yes I’d agree, at root of all this is a clash between direct and representative democracy (which in many respects was always going to happen given how little guidance/precedent there was on how that exercise in direct democracy should be accommodated by representative democracy)
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Controversial argument klaxon: Brexit shows British democracy is actually working. May, don’t forget, fought tooth and nail against any meaningful vote on her deal. She wanted to push her will through Parliament unopposed. Like an autocrat
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: This is why no deal is so likely (the failure of so many UK politicos to see this is strongly redolent of collective group think that failed to see Brexit itself or Trump)
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: I am too. He’s awesome
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Haha was my laughter caught on the mic??
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: The idea that Theresa May ‘knows what the people want’ and MPs are blocking that is pure, naked authoritarian rhetoric
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Very interesting. Seems even in UK the ‘blame the EU narrative’ isn’t holding (Never mind Ireland, despite Brexiters’ hopes)

text: If there is another vote - of any kind - in the UK there will be dozens and dozens of cases of electoral law being broken - really important piece fresh up on @openDemocracy showing just how broken our election laws are

text: That’s low! I only said it was sad it was shut....

text: What’s almost worse is the ex post argument that Ireland and the border is a confected issue. Bad enough to ignore it during the campaign but to pretend afterwards that it doesn’t matter/is a bagatelle
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: That's a very good point! There was a lack of clarity. IMO there is a far greater likelihood of no deal than is being factored in. Simply because no deal is the default and it's looking like May will make it a choice between her deal and no deal at the 11th hour
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Must read piece from my man @OliverNorgrove

text: We are a really small investigative unit dependent on public support to exist. Please do consider donating to support @openDemocracy and our work!
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: "During our meeting, Banks spoke scathingly of the Web site Open Democracy, which has published detailed articles on Banks’s business dealings and political activities." Fantastic! @openDemocracy in @NewYorker on #Brexit and Arron Banks by @edcaesar
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Middle x narratives push political parties more than public opinion (but can also push public opinion.)
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Public opinion and middle X narrative aren’t the same thing (and by my reading until concerns about immigration declined in England recently there was a difference there too)
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: A recent change in English opinion doesn’t mean there’s no difference
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Broadly what’s happened recently is concern about immigration has reduced in England so it’s closer to Scottish levels
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: The difference between Scottish and English sun is incredible
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Public opinion too (by most surveys I’ve seen)
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: The difference between middle England and middle Scotland’s narrative on immigration is huge
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: I can see the logic of this for sure. But logic does seem to be in rather short supply ATM. There’s at least 60 Tory MPs that are likely to bang on so loudly about Europe that the din is heard far beyond the backbenches
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Yes that is true but given the fine margins of UK elections playing to that betrayal narrative could be an effective political strategy....

text: Ah hear you’re normally a lot better than this whataboutery.

text: Whatever happens next week Brexit isn’t going to ‘end’ with May’s deal, it’s going to go on, and on, and on
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Great, look forward to that
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Unfortunately it almost feels to be expected these days. Hope you’re not too rattled by what happened to you (btw it’s been far too long since we last caught up - do give me a shout if you find yourself in Glasgow and we’ll grab a coffee)
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: I can only imagine how this must have made you felt (I had someone singing about the IRA in my face recently and, to be honest, I was terrified). It’s impossible not to feel like these people feel emboldened by the wider political environment
author: PeterKGeoghegan

text: Awful to hear that this has happened to you @asankade.

text: Yep, whether they fold or not now is kinda immaterial. Even a majority of unionists think they’ve made a mess of Brexit
